last_post.content:
Just for old times' sake, my petition to allow US and UK trans and nonbinary people fleeing transphobic laws and a potential genocide to claim asylum in Canada? Well, it closes in just under one week. At the moment, we're about sixteen thousand signatures short of the second-most signatures on any Canadian petition to the government. Ever.

So I'm gonna send this around one more time, with the hope that Canadians will see it, sign it, and pass it along. You will need a Canadian address (a real one) to fill out the form.

https://petitions.ourcommons.ca/en/Petition/Details?Petition=e-4268

Disponible en français ici:

https://petitions.noscommunes.ca/fr/Petition/Details?Petition=e-4268

Thanks for your attention; boosts and x-posts to other social media welcomed.

Day14
You can use many/any platform on the Fediverse, they're not walled off from each other.

Maybe you begin with Calckey (this here)/Misskey or Mastodon or Pixelfed (a bit like Instagram). You will soon appreciate your freedom to add other platforms without having to start over from scratch like with the big corporate social walled enclosures that separate their user bases. I post seamlessly from Calckey to my Mastodon followers for example.

3 helpful sites to explore:

An over view of the Fediverse, a co-operation of social platforms. Imagine Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tiktok, Youtube, Medium, Reddit but co-operating, inter-operating and developing to benefit all the users not some billionaires.
https://jointhefediverse.net/

Calckey servers
https://calckey.org/

Where did your Twitter contacts go? Automatically reconnect to your Twitter people from the many different Fediverse platforms.
https://fedifinder.glitch.me/

#FediTips #Help #New #Newbies #NewHere #Social #Welcome #TwitterMigration #TwitterExodus #SocialMedia #social #SocialMedia #social

title: Humans and algorithms work together — so study them together

last_post.content:
Drop whatever you are doing and take a few minutes to read this piece from @natematias — it's the most important thing I've read this year about the path forward in understanding how information technologies are shaping society, and what we can do to make this a force for good.

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-01521-z

title: This is Instagram’s new Twitter competitor

[1] https://www.theverge.com/2023/5/19/23730070/instagram-twitter-app-competitor-leak

Day 1
Where am I? Is this the Fediverse? What is the Mastodon? How do I Calckey? Am I Pixelfed?
..
👉 Click for Thread🧵
...
What I've learned about #Fediverse (#Mastodon #Calckey etc) condensed to help others.

#FediTips #Help #New #Newbies #NewHere #FediTips #Help #New #Newbies #NewHere #Social #Welcome #TwitterMigration #TwitterExodus

Day15
There is no central architect.

There are some people on the Fediverse who contribute a lot, but there are no Emperors, no Kings. Power is distributed out & shared, and not a pyramid with rulers atop. The rest of the network can just adapt around any figure. The Fediverse can't be bought and sold.

This means my social is not at the whims of negotiating with some central figure, who is unlikely to register I even exist. If I want something different, I can move around the Fediverse to where it's happening that way, even set up my own space if I want.
#Fediverse #FediFriday #FediTips #Help #New #Newbies #NewHere #Social #Welcome #TwitterMigration #TwitterExodus #SocialMedia #social

title: Evaluating Verifiability in Generative Search Engines

last_post.content:
Responses from existing generative search engines (Bing Chat, NeevaAI, this http URL, and YouChat) are fluent and appear informative, but frequently contain unsupported statements and inaccurate citations: 51% of generated sentences are fully supported by citations and only 74% of citations support their associated sentence
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09848

We haven’t yet made a decision regarding whether https://calckey.social will federate with #Barcelona.

I’m of the belief that there needs to be a “lobby” where new people try out software to decide whether they like it, and federation is important for spreading word of mouth.

On the other hand, #Meta has done horrible things to people, and I will never be their friend so long as Zuck and co. run the show.

I question @film_girl@mastodon.social’s assumptions that in order to decentralize we must roll out the welcome mat to the biggest centralizing force on the Internet.

But this isn’t just about centralization, it’s about a well-known peddled of evil arriving on the scene. And I’m not being hyperbolic here. Meta is to social media what Dow is to chemicals.

To everyone who expresses concerns about Meta—you’re right!

RE: https://mastodon.social/users/film_girl/statuses/110398136518629961

"we present an al-
ternative explanation for emergent abilities: that for a particular task and model
family, when analyzing fixed model outputs, one can choose a metric which leads
to the inference of an emergent ability or another...which does not..our alternative suggests that..claims of emergent abilities are creations of the researcher’s analyses, not fundamental changes in model behavior on specific tasks with scale"

Rylan Schaeffer, Brando Miranda, & Sanmi Koyejo

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2304.15004.pdf

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

title: The Archivist and the Revolution by Autumn Chen

last_post.content:
I've updated my interactive fiction, The Archivist and the Revolution (it's at ~62k words now). It's a slice-of-life/anti-romance/history simulator where the world is ending, but you are still paying rent.

Well, I think it's a good game. It placed 4th out of 70 at IFComp 2022.

https://red-autumn.itch.io/archivist

#InteractiveFiction

With #barcelona I don’t think #Meta can pull an Embrace, Extend, Extinguish on the fediverse. People care too much about the #fediverse to leave it for meta.

We don’t know if they’ll keep the activitypub support forever. But it’s more going to be a case of "Yay, we have access. Oh meta closed the access too bad." and we’ll go back separate ways. But the other way around is possible. We CAN convince intagram users to migrate out of meta.

The main problem is elsewhere. What about badly-moderated instagram content ending up in your #mastodon feed? What about bad actors sending you spam, bulling, etc.

Being able to follow your friend who refused to move out of walled garden is GOOD. It’s a net positive. But federation with meta will require some HEAVY filter. I’m talking follows on approval, blocking DMs, not showing posts on the federated timeline, etc.

if you’re looking for a fun and enjoyable game to start your Friday morning:

https://userinyerface.com/

title: “Externally managed environments”: when PEP 668 breaks pip

last_post.content:
“Externally managed environments”: when PEP 668 breaks pip

You’re on a new version of Linux, you try a pip install, and it errors out, talking about “externally managed environments” and “PEP 668”. What’s going on? How do you solve this?

https://pythonspeed.com/articles/externally-managed-environment-pep-668/

title: Language models can explain neurons in language models

last_post.content:
🎯 Explainable AI suffers from an epidemic. I call it Explainability Washing.

💡Think of it as window dressing—techniques, tools, or processes created to provide the illusion of explainability but not delivering it

Let’s use this hyped example from OpenAI. Title is sensational-- Language models can explain neurons in language models.

But is that the case? Let's dig in. 👇

https://openai.com/research/language-models-can-explain-neurons-in-language-models

#AI #ML #XAI #gpt4 #chatGPT #Bard #LLM #NLP #HCI #UX #UI #responsibleai #mastodon
1/n

title: It Will Cost Up to $21.5 Billion to Clean Up California’s Oil Sites. The Industry Won’t Make Enough Money to Pay for It.

last_post.content:
If we priced externalities into the cost of fossil fuels, it’s not a profitable business.

The cleanup costs in California will be triple the industry’s projected profits, and that doesn’t even include cleaning up CO₂ and CH₄ from the atmosphere.

https://www.propublica.org/article/cost-of-california-oil-cleanup-exceeds-industry-profits

title: I downloaded all 1,680,399 posts on Bluesky

last_post.content:
Public townsquare? Permanent record? Full transparency? Bluesky?

Somebody put all of #Bluesky's posts so far in one single database.

Note AFAIK everything that happens on Bluesky is public, and can never be deleted. So this is not a bug, this is a feature, according to their architecture.

https://worthdoingbadly.com/bsky/

Happy Birthday Fediverse!

Gestern vor 15 Jahren hat Evan seinen ersten Post ins Fediverse gesendet:

Fifteen years ago tomorrow I published the first post on the fediverse.

https://web.archive.org/web/20080618164355/http://identi.ca/notice/1

It’s still visible on Identi.ca today, although the URL format changed a few years ago, and the redirect plugin stopped working a few years after that.

https://identi.ca/evan/note/Y0QwGyc1QYilqqawkDrQlg

Thanks to everyone who made identi.ca a great place to be, and thanks to everyone who’s expanded the fediverse since then.

Someday soon-ish I’d like to have identi.ca working with ActivityPub. When I get the time for it!

https://cosocial.ca/@evan/110385636249899888

Vor 15 Jahren!!!

Erst laconi.ca/identi.ca dann status.net und jetzt gnu.social.

Von OpenMicroBlogging über OStatus zu ActivityPub.

Es ist faszinierend wie lange sich die Idee gehalten hat und das unabhängig von der Platform und dem Protocol!

Laut dem Screenshot von meinem Profil, bin ich auch schon seit Juni 2008 dabei.

Happy Birthday und mal schauen wie das Fediverse in 15 Jahren aussieht 😉 !

#activitypub #fediverse #identica #openmicroblogging #ostatus #statusnet

https://notiz.blog/b/6Gg

title: Epistemic diversity and industrial selection bias - Synthese

last_post.content:
Corporations can influence the directions and conclusions of academic research without corrupting the beliefs of any individual scientist. In a phenomenon known as industry selection bias, companies direct funding and/or data toward scientists who already support the research approaches or technological solutions favored by industry.

A new paper out in Synthese expands on the earlier Holman and Bruner model of this scenario to illustrate how this process works.

https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11229-023-04158-7

title: The king’s spice cabinet–Plant remains from Gribshunden, a 15th century royal shipwreck in the Baltic Sea

last_post.content:
1) The shipwreck of the 1495 medieval Danish warship Gribshunden turned out to have incredibly well-preserved plant remains, including expensive spices like saffron, peppercorns, ginger, and almond.

It's a “substantially complete royal medieval pantry” and is "[one of] the most fabulous discoveries of spices in any archaeological context, on land or sea"

View the paper here: https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0281010

#Medieval #Gribshunden #Shipwreck #Archaeology #MaritimeArchaeology #Viking #Vikings #Histodons

title: The Dog Sitter Detective by Antony Johnston

last_post.content: Having the distinct pleasure of reading friend @antonyjohnston’s latest book, The Dog Sitter Detective, just out! https://dogsitterdetective.com Antony is a stellar writer, and this one feels quite personal—it's first person and begins somewhat in media res, just after a crucial event in the protagonist's life. I'm already chortling at many lines—the murder is still imminent—such as “nobody wanted a Falstaff in their Hamlet.” Antony’s love of hounds also shines through!

Day14
You can use many/any platform on the Fediverse, they're not walled off from each other.

Maybe you begin with Calckey (this here)/Misskey or Mastodon or Pixelfed (a bit like Instagram). You will soon appreciate your freedom to add other platforms without having to start over from scratch like with the big corporate social walled enclosures that separate their user bases. I post seamlessly from Calckey to my Mastodon followers for example.

3 helpful sites to explore:

An over view of the Fediverse, a co-operation of social platforms. Imagine Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tiktok, Youtube, Medium, Reddit but co-operating, inter-operating and developing to benefit all the users not some billionaires.
https://jointhefediverse.net/

Calckey servers
https://calckey.org/

title: Symbol tuning improves in-context learning in language models

last_post.content:
Symbol tuning improves in-context learning in language models

Presents symbol tuning—finetuning LMs on in-context input–label pairs where natural language labels (e.g., “positive sentiment”) are replaced with arbitrary symbols (e.g., “foo/bar”).

https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08298

- Summary: Earth Primer is an interactive science book available for iPad and Mac, allowing users to discover and play with Earth's dynamics, including tectonic plates, weather, and the water cycle. It has won several awards for its innovation, design, and appeal for educators. The book unlocks new tools and features as users progress, and a sandbox mode encourages creative exploration. The soundtrack is also available, and support is provided for educators.

title: Slouching towards Gilead: Why the Tory right wants to drag women back to the 1950s

last_post.content:
People have been pointing out for the best part of a decade that the right-wingers using pretend conflicts with women's rights to attack trans people would turn round and attack women's rights too. And surprise surprise, we were right.

And you know what? Liberal newspapers like the Guardian fell for it hook line and sinker, and will now be throwing their hands up in horror at "how it's got to this". We told you. You platformed transphobes and bigots anyway.

https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/the-tory-right-wants-to-drag-women-back-to-the-1950s-b2339899.html
The Fanfic Sex Trope That Caught a Plundering AI Red-Handed - https://www.wired.com/story/fanfiction-omegaverse-sex-trope-artificial-intelligence-knotting/

title: Supreme Court hands tech companies a win, and not just about Section 230

last_post.content:
So much of the debate around social media has focused on Section 230 as the obstacle to holding platforms accountable.

Today's SCOTUS decision showed it's going to be hard to sue tech companies for harmful content even *without* 230. My quick analysis: https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/05/18/scotus-social-media-analysis/

So...
is anyone interested in actually measuring how hard it is to communicate and be heard as a regular person's account on big social vs. Fediverse???
My personal results when I ran a series of experiments using my 1k ish Mastodon following vs 1k ish Twitter following in Nov Dec Jan Feb Mar were frankly astonishing.

@atomicpoet @mmasnick@mastodon.social #SocialMedia #social

title: ICYMI: Instagram's New App Could Be Here By June

last_post.content:
So Meta appears to be making an ActivityPub play [1]. I want to go on record about this, in two ways:

1. Meta has dramatically - like, at least two orders of magnitude - more development labor to throw at this issue. If this software is easier to use or more intuitive to you than Mastodon, Akkoma, Calkey, etc, it's worth taking a moment to acknowledge that this is probably why - and if it's a janky mess, well, that's going to be very funny.

2. This is an Embrace, Extend, Extinguish [2] play, baldfacedly. It's incumbent upon instances whose users are committed to decentralization to at *least* silence, and preferably suspend, corporate takeover attempts like this.

If you care more about reach than decentralization, that's fine; it's a personal choice that someone might make for any number of very valid reasons. I would ask that those of us who *are* ideologically motivated in this way not harass others who can't or don't make that decision.

But.

I would also ask people to kindly refrain from ranting about how ~unreasonable~ it is for Fediverse old-timers to shun corporate ActivityPub instances. Many of us are in this game because we want to see a future where all internet discourse isn't filtered through a half-dozen corporate moderation panels, and we are willing - and able - to make choices based on that.

There is also likely to be a *lot* of spam and bad discourse from that direction, so even if you're not ideologically motivated to avoid corporate nonsense, you might want to.

Thanks.

---

1: Lia Haberman, "ICYMI: Instagram's New App Could Be Here By June " on Stubstack. Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20230519155758/https://liahaberman.substack.com/p/icymi-instagrams-new-app-could-be

2: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embrace,_extend,_and_extinguish

So Meta appears to be making an ActivityPub play [1]. I want to go on record about this, in two ways:

1. Meta has dramatically - like, at least two orders of magnitude - more development labor to throw at this issue. If this software is easier to use or more intuitive to you than Mastodon, Akkoma, Calkey, etc, it's worth taking a moment to acknowledge that this is probably why - and if it's a janky mess, well, that's going to be very funny.

2. This is an Embrace, Extend, Extinguish [2] play, baldfacedly. It's incumbent upon instances whose users are committed to decentralization to at *least* silence, and preferably suspend, corporate takeover attempts like this.

If you care more about reach than decentralization, that's fine; it's a personal choice that someone might make for any number of very valid reasons. I would ask that those of us who *are* ideologically motivated in this way not harass others who can't or don't make that decision.

But.

I would also ask people to kindly refrain from ranting about how ~unreasonable~ it is for Fediverse old-timers to shun corporate ActivityPub instances. Many of us are in this game because we want to see a future where all internet discourse isn't filtered through a half-dozen corporate moderation panels, and we are willing - and able - to make choices based on that.

There is also likely to be a *lot* of spam and bad discourse from that direction, so even if you're not ideologically motivated to avoid corporate nonsense, you might want to.

Thanks.

---

1: Lia Haberman, "ICYMI: Instagram's New App Could Be Here By June " on Stubstack. Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20230519155758/https://liahaberman.substack.com/p/icymi-instagrams-new-app-could-be

2: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embrace,_extend,_and_extinguish

title: Thread by @JKSteinberger on Thread Reader App

last_post.content:
Prof. Julia Steinberger reports
that for 3 full days the EU parliament hosted thousands of scientists, activists and policy-makers charting a future beyond growth, but says every single journalist there she spoke to said, "my editor refuses to print any story critical of economic growth."
She is asking people to spread the word about this.
https://threadreaderapp.com/thread/1659429887751405569.html
#degrowth #beyondgrowth

- The Programmer's Brain
Felienne Hermans: https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/57196550-the-programmer-s-brain?ref=nav_sb_ss_1_20

- The Tech That Comes Next: How Changemakers, Philanthropists, and Technologists Can Build an Equitable World. Amy Sample Ward, Afua Bruce: https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/59862426-the-tech-that-comes-next?ref=nav_sb_ss_1_23

I have enjoyed each one of them.

It is incredible to discover new authors and converse with them in a language other than my native tongue.

I have several more in the reading and even more, waiting for me. So I will be sharing them 🤓 .

3/3

title: AI ‘Cheating’ Is More Bewildering Than Professors Imagined

last_post.content:
Hundreds of words in this essay on the problems AI poses for college professors, but not a word on how class sizes shape the context of assignments and grading. (I’d write very different assignments if I had a lot fewer students, and I would *know my students* well enough to have some context for what they turned in.)

https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2023/05/chatbot-cheating-college-campuses/674073/

title: Discovery certificate for object 2023ixf | Transient Name Server

last_post.content:
New supernova discovered in Pinwheel galaxy (M101)!
https://www.wis-tns.org/object/2023ixf/discovery-cert
#supernova #astronomy

I'll have a blog entry about it soon, but before then, you get to hear about it first: A full transfer of the USC Cinema sound effects library, which includes the work of Sunset Editorial and their hundreds of sound effects.

You can browse the collection here:

https://archive.org/details/usc-sound-effect-archive

Abandoned house and couch, Mojave Desert, California, 2010.

Several more pixels at https://www.flickr.com/photos/mattblaze/4611078542

(Not 16:9; you might need to click to see the whole image)

#photography

title: I wanted to be a teacher but they made me a cop

last_post.content:
I didn’t know about all these experiments with grade deflation, grade reinflation, sealed grades, non-quantitative grades, all resulting in the same mess and stress for students and faculty:

“Grade harder, grade softer, grade with words rather than numbers, hide the grades entirely—none of it works, because the problem was never the grades themselves. The problem was trying to be both a teacher and a cop at the same time.” https://www.experimental-history.com/p/i-wanted-to-be-a-teacher-but-they

Like the author I’m surprised that telling kids their grades literally don’t exist doesn’t let them focus on learning (or not learning).

But I think the problem is deeper. It doesn’t make sense to me to cordon off learning into a separate time and a separate place from the rest of your life. “This is School. You’re supposed to learn for the whole time you’re here.” What? Makes no sense! Even night classes for working adults make little sense, because life happens and you can’t properly cordon off learning into “this 16 week course”.

To me, I think educational experiences should always be self-paced and untimed. Some courses online are like this: “here’s the videos, here’s the assignments, do them whenever, if you cheat I mean you already paid for it upfront and you’re not getting anything after you finish, here’s a forum you can ask questions, along this list of the standard places on the web people interested in this topic hang out, and you can always email me kthxbai”.

(Sorry I know discussion-based courses can’t work this way but since I’ve never taken a discussion-based course I have no thoughts about them.)

title: SSE Library: VOICES : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
And for the real sound nerds, there's even the recording of the original Wilhelm Scream, including the sound engineers getting the actor to try different sounds before hitting the famous one:

https://archive.org/details/SSE_Library_VOICES/SCREAM/VOXScrm_Man+eaten+by+alligator%3B+screams+%5BWilhelm_CS_USC.wav

🎁Starter pack to avoid Explainability Washing:

1) Don’t just assert it’s an explanation, justify how it is so: focus on the why-question [B,C]

2) Identify *who* the users are + *how* it helps them to *do* something [A, B]

3) Focus on *who* is opening the black-box, not just on opening it [A]

[A] The Who in XAI: https://twitter.com/UpolEhsan/status/1421142478229540867?t=0QmE6_gigEIAsdVYWMUYCQ&s=19

[B] Expanding Explainability: https://arxiv.org/abs/2101.04719

[C] XAI + Social Science: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0004370218305988

5/5 (n=5)
